user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_QueueDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                            return_code;
    OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token);

    /* Try to delete and unlink the queue */
    if (mq_close(impl->id) != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("OS_QueueDelete Error during mq_close(). errno = %d (%s)\n", errno, strerror(errno));
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueueDelete_Impl:
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
typedef struct
{
    mqd_t id;
} OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t OS_impl_queue_table[OS_MAX_QUEUES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: OS_DEBUG("OS_QueueDelete Error during mq_close(). errno = %d (%s)\n", errno, strerror(errno));
explanation: Only the OS_DEBUG(...) line contains a call to a string-handling library function (strerror) that originates from <string.h>. The rest of the code does not use any of the string.h functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.), nor does it pass pointer parameters to such functions that could result in out-of-bounds accesses. The mq_close call and the object-table index macro do not involve <string.h> string-handling operations. Note: OS_DEBUG is defined as empty in the provided additional code, so its arguments would typically be removed by the preprocessor in this configuration; however the presence of strerror in the source means it should be investigated in case OS_DEBUG is configured differently or the call is enabled in other build variants.
